rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The aerobic metabolism of glucose by Ehrlich ascites tumor cells.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In Ehrlich ascites tumor cells, the production of CO2 from glucose carbon-l is mainly due to glucose oxidation via the HMP shunt. The remaining carbon atoms are converted to pentose phosphates and can subsequently be degraded to lactate, as indicated by studies with modified cells. The lactate produced may then be oxidized to CO2 as a result of the operation of the TCA cycle. Glucose oxidation via the HMP shunt is controlled by the rate of NADPH oxidation. NADPH oxidation may involve the malic enzyme, the reduction of pyruvate and fatty acid synthesis. Adenosine, which inhibits shunt activity in Ehrlich ascites cells, acts by diminishing NADPH oxidation. The rate of oxidation of glucose- 1-14C is also decreased when the intracellular ATP level is depleted by preincubating the cells with glucose plus oxamate. When the ATP level is restored by incubating the cells with glucose plus adenine, the decrease in shunt activity is also reversed.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Studies on the conformational stability of a human cryoglobulin.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Studies on a human cryoglobulin (gamma-I : lambda, Gm 4) revealed that this protein displayed a reversible "gel to and from sol" phenomenon depending on the pH and temperature of the suspending media. Alkaline dissociation of cryoglobulin was first noticed at pH 11.75, accompanied by irreversible conformational changes. All 62 tyrosyl groups became available in 5 M guanidine-HCl. The greater was the disruptive field induced by perturbants (pH, temperature and ionic and non-ionic solutes), the greater was the irreversible deformation. Transition temperatures of cryoglobulin, its Fab and Fl(ab)2 fragments as measured by fluorescence emission intensity were 63°, 65.6°, and 65.7°, respectively. Perturbants produced varying degrees of inhibition in the antibody-combining capacity. The Fc and lambda-determinant sites were alkali-resistant while cryoglobulin-specific determinant sites were alkali labile. The lamda-determinant sites were resistant to heat-denaturation. Self-association of cryoglobulin Fab (mol. wt., 44,600) and Fl(ab)2 (mol. wt., 105,600) was observed depending on temperature, protein concentration and pH of the suspending media. Both F1(ab)2 and F2(ab)2 (mol. wt., 93,000) displayed visible cryo-gel formation, the efficiency being dependent on molecular size. Reduced-alkylated H-chains of cryoglobulin also exhibited gel formation.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Medicine.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Biochemical studies on GM1-gangliosidosis.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: GMl-gangliosidosis is an inherited disease quite distinct from Tay-Sachs and Hurler's diseases. It exists in two clinical forms. These studies were initiated on a patient with the Type II form. GMl-ganglioside was accumulated in the brain and beta-galactosidase activity of brain, leucocytes and cultured skin fibroblasts was 2-6% of normal. The leucocyte S-galactosidase activity of the parents (carriers) was 50% of normal. Two glycosaminoglycan fractions were isolated from the urine. Both CPC- and non-CPC-precipitable fractions contained large amounts of galactose-glucosamine-containing materials of the keratan sulfate type but they were undersulfated. Glycosaminoglycans of similar composition were isolated in large amounts from the liver of a Type l patient. They were polydisperse, not CPC-precipitable, had an alkali-labile protein polysaccharide linkage region and were similar to keratan sulfate. The cultured fibroblasts of Type II contained two gangliosides not found in normal cell cultures. The glycosaminoglycans, labeled by incubation with l4C-galactose and l4C-glucosamine, accumulated in the Type II cells and were similar to those found in the urine and in the liver.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Hydrolysis of carnitine and choline esters by cholinesterases.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The hydrolysis of acetyl-dl-carnitylcholine, I-carnitylcholine and acetyl-dl-carnitine by the cholinester hydrolases was investigated. The ester bonds of acetyl-dl-carnitylcholine were hydrolyzed by the acetylcholinesterases (rat brain, human and bovine erythrocyte enzymes) to the extent of 25 per cent. The hydrolysis appeared to be stereospecific. Acetyl-dl-carnitylcholine was hydrolyzed slightly by purified human serum but not by fresh human plasma or purified horse serum cholinesterases. Several preparations of both acetylcholinesterase and cholinesterase failed to hydrolyze I-carnitylcholine and acetyl-dl-carnitine. These three compounds, as well as several other choline esters, competitively inhibited acetylcholinesterase hydrolysis of acetylthiocholine. Acetyl-dl-camitylcholine had marked affinity for acetylchol inesterase whereas acetyl-dl-carnitine and choline were very weak inhibitors. The products of hydrolysis of acetyl-dl-carnitylcholine by acetylcholinesterase were acetylcarnitine and choline. The significance of these end-products in metabolism is discussed.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The interfacial properties of polymers in the liquid state.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The Prigogine corresponding states principle for the bulk properties of liquids has been extended to their surface tensions. A single gamma(T) curve is obtained for some forty polyatomic liquids and five high polymers. The prigogine-Saraga cell model theory of surface tension is used together with several models of the liquid state to predict the empirical curves. The surface tensions and entropies of some polyethers, their mixtures and their random and block copolymers were determined by the pendant drop method. In all cases, except the random copolymers, a surface excess of the low surface energy component has been found. The data have been analyzed in the light of the most complete theories to date. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A modal approach to induction motor dynamics.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The acceleration transients and the asymptotic stability of the balanced 3-phase induction motor operating from a balanced single frequency voltage supply have been investigated by a combination of numerical techniques and analytical methods. A critical review is given for the various reference frame formulations of the induction motor dynamics and the efficiency of the methods for solving the dynamic equations has been assessed. The modal approach is presented as a comprehensive framework around which the numerical results are systematically organized and such disparate subjects as acceleration transients, asymptotic stability and nonsimultaneous switching are unified. Detailed attention is given to the identification of the physical modes and to understanding their behavioral changes as a function of rotor speeds. Asymptotic stability is studied by linearization through small signal perturbations. Quadratic liapunov Functions are proposed and it is shown that a Liapunov Function associated with the Total Energy con be used to prove Asymptotic Stability in the large. Eigenvalue sensitivity with respect to system parameters is also presented. The m.m.f. spacevector viewpoint is presented to give a physical description of the modes, the airgap magnetic field interactions in the production of transient torque, and the possibility of supersynchronous speeds during transients.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Electrical Engineering.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Measurement of snowfall by radar.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Two aspects of one major snowstorm were analysed using 3-cm radar observations taken at a number of heights: (i) the correlation of radar returns taken at low heights with snowfall measurements at the ground, (ii) the variation of radar returns with height, and with time. For 20 grid points within 42-miles range, the ratio of amounts measured by radar at 5000 ft to amounts measured at the ground had a log normal distribution, the standard deviation corresponding to ratio 1.3 and its reciprocal. It was found that useful measurements of snowfall amount could be derived from radar observations out to 100-miles range, and that the variation of snowfall rate at a point could be determined from observations taken earlier along the trajectory of the snow falling toward that point. Radar data from greater heights showed that more than 95% of the snow that fell within 100-miles range had been generated below 20,000 ft, and that the growth of snow with distance fallen varied in space and time. Thus in regions north of the radar hall the growth was at heights between 10000 ft and 5000 ft; in regions south of the radar half the growth was between 15000 and 10000 feet.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Meteorology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Studies in geomagnetic micropulsations.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The theory of correlation functions and power spectral analyses is reviewed. Analog spectral analyses are then made of orthogonal components of geomagnetic micropulsations to investigate (a) the diurnal variation of pcs at a given station, (h) spatial variation of pcs at three pairs of stations differing respectively by 500 in longitude, 5.6° in latitude and 15° in latitude. Analog crosscorrelation technique is employed to study the phase relations among the three orthogonal components, both for pcs (pc-3 and pc-4) and pi-2 at a given station. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mining Engineering.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Biological, immunological and physiochemical properties of gamma-D immunoglobulin (IgD).
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The recently discovered and relatively unstudied immunoglobulin, gamma-D, was investigated to further elucidate its nature. It was found to be virtually absent from umbilical cord blood and to increase until age 6 when adult serum levals were attained. The mean serum level of gamma-D was found to be elevated in cystic fibrosis of the pancreas, in Laennec's cirrhosis and in infants with the visceral larva migrans syndrome, but was decreased in hypoagammaglobulinemia. Small quantities were found in normal saliva, colostrum and breast milk. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Medicine.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Cardiac metabolism in vitro with special reference to the role of calcium.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The effects of Ca++ , Na+ , K+ , ouabain, epinephrine and tetrodotoxin (TTX) on the metabolism of glucose-U-C14 in the perfused guinea pig heart were studied. A direct relationship was found between glucose oxidation and the extracellular ratio (Ca++)/(Na+)2. The metabolic stimulatory effects of ouabain were concentration-dependent and were prevented at half and twice Ca++, at zero K+, by MnC12 and by acetate. The addition of malonate, TTX or K+ caused a reduction of the metabolic activity obtained with ouabain, but dichloroisoproterenol and theophylline caused no effect. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The vertical propagation of geostrophic waves in a low-order spectral model.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The Vertical propagation of geostrophic waves is studied by means of time integrations of a spectral baroclinic model of high vertical resolution. The results are compared with the predictions of linear theory and the energy transfers between the propagating wave and the zonal flow are calculated. Short waves are trapped near the bottom of the model, as expected, but planetary waves propagate vertically through both easterly and strong westerly zonal winds. Interaction of the propagating wave with the zonal current produces a high-level wind reversal, in the latter case, analagous to stratospheric sudden warmings.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Meteorology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Development of mercantilism : a study in government intervention in trade, industry and agriculture in England and France during the sixteenth to eighteenth centuries.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This study is an attempt to use the method of historical analysis to answer the question: "Is Government intervention in the economic sphere to become a permanent feature of our everyday life or will it be only a bridge which is going to lead us to a better and more harmonious economy in a free world?" The thesis consists of four parts: Part I deals with the general aspects of the problem. The views of twelve economists are analyzed and the principles underlying the problem methodically examined. The period of transition from feudal to capitalist economy, the growth of the national state and its influence upon economic activities are briefly discussed. Part II describes conditions in England during the sixteenth to eighteenth centuries, the attempts of the governments to intervene in all spheres of economic activity, and the views held by outstanding mercantilists. Similarly, conditions in France are discussed in Part III. The administration of Colbert, the great minister of Finance, is methodically examined. Part IV deals with the decline of the doctrines favouring government intervention and reviews critically the methods, extent and results of mercantilist policy. Through the courtesy of the Public Archives at Ottawa, a few illustrations and a map showing British and French colonial possessions in 1713 are included.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mercantile system -- Great Britain.
Industrial policy -- France -- History.
Industrial policy -- Great Britain -- History.
Great Britain -- Economic policy -- History.
Mercantile system -- France.
France -- Economic policy -- History.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Steady state regional gas exchange in health and disease studied with 133Xe.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: By inducing a steady state of 133Xe exchange across the lung and measuring the 133Xe concentration in individual lung regions, we were able to measure steady state regional ventilation/perfusion ratios (VA/Q). This technique was combined with independent assessments of regional ventilation and blood flow, and a variety of subjects studied. Erect normal subjects showed an apex-to-base gradient in VA/Q which, though sizable, did not explain all VA/Q variation reported in such lungs. Seated post-pneumonectomy patients wew examined; the increased flow through the remaining lung decreased, apex-to-base differences in perfusion and VA/Q, but ventilation distribution was unchanged. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Medicine.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Experimental and theoretical investigation of vestibularly-driven head and eye movement.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This is a study of the vestibulo-ocular and vestibulo-collic reflexes, two neuromuscular control systems providing velocity stabilization of eye and head respectively, relative to space. As well as having a common role in visual image stabilization, the two systems share the same angular velocity sensor, the semicircular canal, and the responses of both are complicated by the occurrence of saccades, or quick re-positioning flicks which permit intermittent velocity stabilization (between flicks), even during movements whose amplitude exceeds the limits of eye or head excursion respectively. In the vestibulo-collic system further complexity arises because of direct mechanical feedback of the canal signal. Detailed study of these interrelated dynamic systems requires mathematical analysis, with careful consideration of possible dynamic properties of system components. Accordingly, three major themes are developed, all to some extent based on control theoretical principles, i.e. critical analysis of previous work, theoretical studies, and experimental investigations. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physiology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Sites of synthesis and pathway of migration of glycoprotein in the ameloblast.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Using tritium-labelled monosaccharides as tracers, the synthesis, intracellular transport and secretion of glycoprotein was investigated in the ameloblast by radioautography. Light microscope radioautographs at 2-1/2 - 5 minutes after intravenous 3H-galactose injection demonstrated a localized supranuclear reaction. A similar pattern was observed using 3H-fucose or 3H-glucosamine. In contrast, 3H-glucose and 3H-mannose produced a diffuse cytoplasmic reaction. By 20 minutes, all labels had migrated to the apical process-enamel matrix zone. Electron microscope radioautographs showed 3H-galactose label in Golgi saccules at early intervals. Puromycin had little effect on 3H-galactose incorporation, and label was not removable with alpha amylase. At 10 minutes, labelled secretory granules were in the Golgi zone. By 20 - 30 minutes, grains were over granules in the apical process and over matrix. These observations suggest that glucose and mannose incorporation occurs in the rER. Glycoprotein then migrates to the Golgi where galactose, fucose and glucosamine are added. Completed glycoprotein then migrates via granules to enamel matrix.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Anatomy.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Studies on the extracorporeal heart: problems related to prolonged storage of cardiac allografts.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A canine heart perfusion and evaluation circuit was constructed which incorporated a membrane oxygenator. The heart could be evaluated hemodynamically and metabolically while performing a "normal" work load. Excised hearts were evaluated immediately and compared with hearts stored at 30°C. and at 21°C. There was no significant hemodynamic difference in the three groups while performing on the evaluation circuit. Metabolically, pyruvate excretion occurred at higher work loads in the stored groups in contrast to the uptake of the unstored hearts. An artificial pacemaker was usually effective in maintaining a regular beating heart at lower temperatures. The regular rhythm seemed to reduce cardiac edema. The oxygen uptake of the isolated heart was thoroughly studied and found to be within the oxygen carrying capacity of filtered plasma. This was evaluated as a perfusate and oxygenation and acid base balance were maintained. There was a tendency to myocardial edema which reduced left ventricular contractile force during 24-hour perfusions with plasma. Myocardial deterioration was heralded by a rise in perfusate phosphorus content.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Surgery.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Interaction of human allergen-binding antibodies with heterologous cells.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: 1. By comparing various antibody activities in serum chromatographic fractions from three ragweed atopic patients, evidence was obtained that human reaginic antibodies do not mediate the indirect basophil de granulation reaction. The human ragweed-binding antibodies interacting with rabbit basophils for degranulation were shown to be of the 19 S and 7 S varieties, the latter probably a gamma-G globuline 2. By immunofluorescent techniques it was shown that following incubation of monkey skin with sera of ragweed atopic individuals, the ragweed-binding antibodies fix exclusively to the skin mast cells, and that these cells constitute target cells of human reaginic, IgE antibodies. By immunofluorescent and column chromatographic studies it was shown that non-reaginic, ragweed-binding antibodies ether than IgG, IgA, IgM and IgD, present in the sera of hypesensitized individuals also fix to the monkey skin mast cells.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Medicine.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Studies of the response to hemorrhagic hypotension in the domestic fowl (Gallus domesticus).
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Chickens (and turkeys) present a characteristic pattern of response following hemorrhage which is markedly different from that of mammals (and diving birds). Generally, there are three differences between the reaction of these birds and that of mammals during experimental hemorrhagic hypotension. First, the mean arterial pressure of both species of fowl falls very rapidly after even a small hemorrhage; second, hemodilution is both more rapid and larger in the birds; and finally, chickens do not appear to develop hemoconcentration and the "irreversibility" which is characteristic of hemorrhagic shock in mammals. Results of hemodynamic studies on chickens reported here led to the proposal that all these phenomena are related to a lack of active vasoconstriction. The evidence suggests that absence of active vasoconstriction may be partly due to chronic tachyphylaxis resulting from high levels of circulating catecholamines.

Après hémorragie, on aperçoit, chez la volaille ainsi que chez la dinde, des réponses physiologiques étalées d'une façon bien caractéristique et qui diffèrent remarquablement de celles aperçues chez les mammifères (ainsi que chez les oiseaux plongeurs). Généralement, nous trouvons qu'il existe trois différences entre la réaction de ces oiseaux et celle des mammifères durant l'hypotension hémorragique expérimentale. Premièrement, même à la suite d'une petite hémorragie, la pression artérielle moyenne des deux espèces d'oiseaux tombe très rapidement; deuxièmement, chez les oiseaux, l'hémodilution est à la fois plus rapide et plus grande; enfin, les volailles ne semblent développer ni l'hémoconcentration, ni l'irréversibilitée, ces phénomènes étant caractéristiques des chocs hémorragiques chez les mammifèresé. Les résultats de recherches hémodynamiques obtenus ici ont conduit à la proposition que tous ces phénomènes sont reliés à un manque de vasoconstriction active. L'évidence des faits suggère que cette absence de vasoconstriction active pourrait être partiellement dûe à une tachyphylaxie chronique causée par un niveau élevé de catécholamines dans la circulation.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Pharmacology and Therapeutics.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Some pharmacological and biochemical properties of carnitylcholine.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Evidence obtained from in vivo and in vitro studies on chicks, rats, guinea pigs, rabbits and cats demonstrated that synthetic carnitylcholine was a potent neuromuscular blocking agent of the depolarizing type, capable of producing a non-depolarizing block. Carnitylcholine was not susceptible to the action of acetylcholinesterase, butyrylcholinesterase, choline acetylase or carnitylacetyl transferase. The resistance of carnitylcholine to the action of acetylcholinesterase and butyrylcholinesterase was reflected in its capacity to produce a prolonged neuromuscular block in all species studied. This compound was found to be a weak competitive inhibitor of both acetylcholinesterase and butyrylcholinesterase. However, it is likely that the capacity of carnitylcholine to potentiate the maximal twitch is independent of its anticholinesterase activity. Attempts to identify a carnitylcholine-like metabolite in serum from myasthenia gravis patients were unsuccessful.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Factors affecting esterification of linoleate by human erythrocytes.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The study pertains to the incorporation of linoleate-I-14C into the lipids of human erythrocytes in vitro and the influence of various factors and conditions on the process. Lecithin was found to contain the highest proportion of the labelled fatty acid, and none of the fatty acid was found in the neutral lipids. Glucose caused a slight increase in incorporation in erythrocytes which had been stored for 18 hours at 4°C, but had little effect on fresh cells. Esterification was proportional to the intracellular nucleotide labile phosphate level (corresponding to the ATP and ADP levels), provided the labile phosphate was less than that found in fresh erythrocytes. However, no further increase in esterification occurred when the level of the nucleotide labile phosphate was raised to twice that of fresh cells by incubation of the cells for 10 hours with glucose and adenine. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Mechanical properties of the ventilatory system and their contribution to stability of ventilation.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In decerebrate cats, and in consciousman, mechanical properties of the respiratory system were studied during electrical stimulation of the diaphragm. With a fixed stimulus, at constant lung volume, transdiaphragmatic pressure decreases with increasing airflow, and at constant airflow transdiaphragmatic pressure decreases with increasing lung volume. Taking into account these properties of the respiratory system observed during diaphragmatic contraction, and also the pattern and frequency of breathing, it can be predicted that during spontaneous breathing the ventila tory pump should resist changes in tidal volume brought about by mechanical loading to a degree much greater than that expected on the basis of its mechanical properties under passive conditions. Experimental elastic loading of respiration in human subjects verified this prediction, and showed also that this 'stability' to changes in mechanical load increased with increasing ventilation. Stability under these circumstances was increased partly by increased respiratory frequency, and partly by further mechanical changes.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physiology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Mode of action of alpha-methyl-dl-tryptophan on hepatic glyconeogenesis.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: AMTP (alpha-methyl-dl-tryptophan) stimulates the conversion of amino acids, acetate and pyruvate to hepatic glycogen in rats. Accompanying this phenomenon there is an enhanced rate of oxidation of these substances (except acetate) to carbon dioxide. The action of AMTP on glutamate and pyruvate oxidation is dependent upon the adrenal gland; for leucine, isoleucine, alanine and threonine, the effect is only partially dependent; for histidine it is independent of the adrenal. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Physiological factors in micro-embolic renal ischemic hypertension.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The purpose of the investigations reported in this thesis was to test the hypothesis of Doctor Séan Moore, that platelet emboli arising from complicated les ions of the aorta, above the renal orifices, were responsible for the renal arteriolar nephrosclerosis commonly seen in human essential hypertension. A technique was devised whereby a catheter bearing exposed magnesium-aluminum wire was placed in the thoracic aortas of rabbits, dogs, rats and monkeys. This embolic source resulted in scattered areas of renal cortical atrophy which were subtended by arterioles showing extensive intimal hyperplasia. The medial cells of these arterioles, especially in the rabbit, were transformed to granule-containing cells with supposed secretory function. Animals with this lesion became hypertensive. A correlative study of renal renin, plasma renin, renal arteriolar granularity and hypertension revealed that in the acute phase of micro-embolic hypertension there is evidence for the participation of renin-angiotensin system; however, in the chronic phase there is none.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physiology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Studies on the primary structure of DNA: I. Improvement of a method for pyrimidine cluster analysis. II. Isolation of DNA sequences complementary to Escherichia coli transfer RNA.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: I. Pyrimidine cluster analysis of DNA was studied by means of the formic acid-diphenylamine degradation and DEAE-cellulose chromatography. A good resolution of pyrimidine clusters of different chain lengths was obtained. The distributions of pyrimidine clusters determined by spectrophotometric measurement and phosphorus analysis before and after enzymatic dephosphorylation confirmed the specificity of the method. II. A tRNA cistron-hybrid, a molecule consisting of a transfer RNA (tRNA) hybridized to its complementary DNA sequences, was isolated. The approach used consisted of hybridizing denatured E.coli DNA with E.coli tRNA and separating the DNA-tRNA hybrid from unhybridized tRNA by gel filtration. The DNA-tRNA hybrid was treated with N.crassa endonuclease, an enzyme specific for single-stranded nucleic acids. This treatment released a tRNA cistron-hybrid from double-stranded DNA regions formed by re-annealing of DNA strands during hybridization. The tRNA cistron-hybrid was isolated from the reaction mixture by successive purification procedures.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The immediate ventilatory response to added elastic loads in cats.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The immediate (first breath) response of cats to added inspiratory elastic loads was studied in eight tracheotomized animals. With increasing loads tidal volume diminished and end-inspiratory tracheal pressure became progressively more negative with respect to the atmosphere. This response was linear, and independent of volume over a range of ventilation equivalent to twice the normal tidal volume. The equivalent elastance value could be computed from the control tidal volume and the pressure developed when the airway was occluded at FRC. The effective elastance so measured permitted the calculation of load-response curves. Using a technique based on these findings, it was determined that immediate load-compensation in the cat is provided chiefly by the diaphragm and the intercostal muscles. The former contribution is largely a function of the diaphragm's intrinsic properties, whereas the intercostal response results from recruitment of additional motor units and is dependent on the integrity of the vagus.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physiology.
